International studies during my doctoral studies (KTH).

By Thomas Gumbricht Google scholar Researchgate Scopus Linkedin Orcid

Contents - Journal articles - Refereed chapters - Reports - Conference proceedings - Training - Images

During my doctoral studies and as a researcher at the Royal Institute of Technology (KTH) I supervised a dozen Msc projects, and led international excursions to Holland, Cyprus and Latvia. After the iron curtain fell in 1989 (I happened to be in Berlin when the wall came down, and in Prague during the velvet revolution), I worked with Polish universities for several years. Through students in the international MSc programmes on Environmental Engineering and Sustainable Infrastructure, that I was instrumental for setting up at KTH, I also worked in Latvia and Lithuania.

I took a large interest in didactics, and presented my approaches at different conferences, and also published a journal article.

My knowledge in Spanish led to shorter projects in Nicaragua (protecting the Managua aquifer), Panama (water balance for the Panama canal), Colombia (Hydrological modeling), and Brazil (I could understand Portuguese and was in Brazil during the Rio 2002 meeting). As part of my doctoral studies

I also spent longer periods in Austria (International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis - IIASA, studying ocean biota and climate change) Ireland (University college Galway studying hydrology), New Zealand (studying wetlands for waste water treatment) and Germany (TU Berlin, studying landscape ecology).

Journal articles

  • Gumbricht, T. et al., Water Resources Development 1997. GIS Integrated Modelling of a Himalayan Landscape.
  • Gumbricht, T., McCarthy, J., & Mahlander, C., Ecological Engineering 1996. Digital interpretation and management of land cover — a case study of Cyprus.
  • Gumbricht, T, Journal of Environmental Management 1996. Application of GIS in Training for Environmental Management.
  • Gumbricht, T., Vatten 1991. Water resources management in Germany – with examples from Niedersachsen.

Refereed chapters

  • Chmiel, J., & Gumbricht, T., International Archives of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing 1996. Knowledge based classification of landscape objects combining satellite and ancillary data.

Reports

  • Gumbricht, T, Royal Institute of Technology (KTH), Stockholm (TRITA-KUT 92:1069). 1992. The role of ocean biota in the CO2 drama.

Conference proceedings

  • Gumbricht, T., McCarthy; J and Hessling, M, Proceedings ScanGIS´97 (pp 209-215) 1997. Modelling the Managua aquifer. 2: groundwater dynamics.
  • McCarthy, J., M. Hessling and T. Gumbricht,, Proceedings ScanGIS´97 (pp 201-208) 1997. Modelling the Managua aquifer. 1: data creation in a developing region.
  • Stenström, P. and Gumbricht, T., Proceedings ScanGIS´97 (pp 216-228) 1997. Catchment-scale modelling of erosion and reservoir sedimentation.
  • Gumbricht, T. Hessling: M and McCarthy, J., Nordic Hydrological Conference (Vol. 40, pp. 529-537) 1996. Hydrological modelling integrating landscape pattern - A case study of Cyprus.
  • Gumbricht, T., Mahlander, C., & McCarthy, J., ScanGIS 1995 Proceedings 1996. Rule based and contextual classification of landscape patches and boundaries.
  • Gumbricht, T., Hydrological processes in the catchment 1995. Watershed structure and symmetry with runoff and water quality.
  • Gumbricht, T., Stockholm Water Symposium 1993. Minimum entropy in small farming - Children’s ecological village Tatui.
